elements.content: On the basis of a temperature-induced effect, the solvothermal reaction of Co­(Ac)2·4H2O, 5-amino-2,4,6-triiodoisophthalic acid (H2atibdc), and 1,4-bis­(2-methyl-imidazol-1-yl)­butane (bib) at 80 °C gave a new coordination polymer [Co­(bib)­(atibdc)] (1), which shows a two-dimensional (2D) network with left- and right-handed helical chains. By raising the reaction temperature to 130 °C, a pair of homochiral enantiomers [Co­(bib)­(atibdc)]­·2H2O (2, 2M, and 2P) were successfully obtained, displaying a three-dimensional (3D) framework with three kinds of unique helical chains. Keeping the temperature of the reaction system to 150 °C, excited, an in situ iodine elimination reaction occurred, and a new linker 5-aminoisophthalic acid (H2aipa) was generated, which then cooperated with the bib ligand to construct a coordination polymer [Co­(bib)­(aipa)] (3), showing a 3D 3-fold interpenetrating architecture. The comparison of final solid structures exhibits an exclusive temperature-induced effect on the construction of the coordination polymer. Furthermore, via a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation, the 2D network of 1 can be derived from the 3D framework of 2, which presents a rare type of temperature-solvent induced SCSC transformation. In addition, the magnetic properties of 1–3 have been investigated as well.

By raising the reaction temperature to 130 °C, a pair of homochiral enantiomers [Co(bib)(atibdc)]⋅2H2O (2, 2M, and 2P) were successfully obtained, displaying a three-dimensional (3D) framework with three kinds of unique helical chains. The comparison of final solid structures exhibits an exclusive temperature-induced effect on the construction of the coordination polymer. Furthermore, via a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SCSC) transformation, the 2D network of 1 can be derived from the 3D framework of 2, which presents a rare type of temperature-solvent induced SCSC transformation. In addition, the magnetic properties of 1-3 have been investigated as well.

elements.content: Three new Co­(II) coordination polymers have been constructed from the same materials based on a temperature-induced effect, as well as iodine elimination, enantiomers resolution, and single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation.
elements.clean_text: Three new Co(II) coordination polymers have been constructed from the same materials based on a temperature-induced effect, as well as iodine elimination, enantiomers resolution, and single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation.

elements.content: Because of the intriguing structures and potential application in gas storage, molecular recognition, magnetism, chiral separation, and catalysis, studies on the synthesis and design of coordination polymers (CPs) are presently of considerable interest. As we know, all applications of CPs are based on their internal microstructures. Thus, rational selection of metal centers and organic ligands with suitable shape, functionality, flexibility, and symmetry makes a pivotal role in regulating structures and properties of CPs. However, to date, it remains a considerable challenge to control the structures of CPs for some external factors, such as solvent, pH, and temperature which exert important impacts on the structures of compounds. Any subtle change of one of the foregoing factors may lead to a drastic change in the dimensionality and topology. Therefore, systematic investigation of an assembling system with the fixed metal centers and coordination organic molecules is crucial for gaining expected target product. One controlling factor in determining the ultimate topology of CPs, which has not been widely employed to date, is temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Because of the intriguing structures and potential application in gas storage, molecular recognition, magnetism, chiral separation, and catalysis, studies on the synthesis and design of coordination polymers (CPs) are presently of considerable interest. As we know, all applications of CPs are based on their internal microstructures. Thus, rational selection of metal centers and organic ligands with suitable shape, functionality, flexibility, and symmetry makes a pivotal role in regulating structures and properties of CPs. However, to date, it remains a considerable challenge to control the structures of CPs for some external factors, such as solvent, pH, and temperature which exert important impacts on the structures of compounds. Any subtle change of one of the foregoing factors may lead to a drastic change in the dimensionality and topology. Therefore, systematic investigation of an assembling system with the fixed metal centers and coordination organic molecules is crucial for gaining expected target product. One controlling factor in determining the ultimate topology of CPs, which has not been widely employed to date, is temperature.

elements.content: Beyond that, as an effective synthetic route, the in situ generation of novel ligands under hydro- or solvothermal conditions, then incorporating them into the final structure, has attracted special attention for new organic syntheses and unexpected coordination complexes since it was proposed by Champness and Schröder in 1997. In situ ligand transformation is one of the promising methods to reduce synthetic steps and also to fabricate new functional pores that are otherwise inaccessible by the conventional stepwise synthesis. Moreover, an in situ method is highly viable for the synthesis of multitopic organic ligands with a varying scale of denticity. Up to now, numerous types of in situ ligand reactions such as carbon C–C coupling, hydroxylation, substitution, alkylation, hydrolysis, oxidation–hydrolysis, cycloaddition, acylation, amination, and decarboxylation have been documented and comprehensively reviewed by Zhang and Chen. Nevertheless, the in situ iodine elimination reaction has never been observed in the synthesis of CPs.

Nevertheless, the in situ iodine elimination reaction has never been observed in the synthesis of CPs.

elements.content: Fortunately, through adjusting the reaction temperatures, we successfully prepared three Co­(II) CPs based on the mixed rigid 5-amino-2,4,6-triiodoisophthalic acid (H2atibdc) and flexible 1,4-bis­(2-methyl-imidazol-1-yl)­butane (bib) ligands (). 1 and 2 are supramolecular isomeric, namely, [Co­(bib)­(atibdc)] (1) and [Co­(bib)­(atibdc)]­·2H2O (2, 2M, and 2P). 3 was constructed from 5-aminoisophthalic acid (H2aipa) which was assembled through in situ ligand transformation with the formula of [Co­(bib)­(aipa)]. Synthesis, structures, iodine elimination, enantiomers resolution, single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation, and magnetic properties were investigated.

elements.content: 1,4-Bbis­(2-methyl-imidazol-1-yl)­butane was synthesized according to the literature. Other reactants for the synthesis were purchased commercially and were used without further purification. The IR spectra using KBr pellets were recorded on a FT-IR 170 SX (Nicolet) spectrophotometer (4000–400 cm–1 region). Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined using a PerkinElmer 2400C automatic analyzer. The solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra were carried out by using JASCO Corporation J-715 spectrometer using KBr disks. An energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) measurement was performed with an X-ray energy dispersive spectrometer installed on a JEOL-6701F microscope. The TGA measurements were carried out with a NETZSCH TG 209 thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (CuK, 1.5418 Å). Magnetic measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-7 SQUID magnetometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

1,4-Bbis(2-methyl-imidazol-1-yl)butane was synthesized according to the literature. Other reactants for the synthesis were purchased commercially and were used without further purification. The IR spectra using KBr pellets were recorded on a FT-IR 170 SX (Nicolet) spectrophotometer (4000-400 cm-1 region). Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined using a PerkinElmer 2400C automatic analyzer. The solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra were carried out by using JASCO Corporation J-715 spectrometer using KBr disks. An energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) measurement was performed with an X-ray energy dispersive spectrometer installed on a JEOL-6701F microscope. The TGA measurements were carried out with a NETZSCH TG 209 thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (CuK, 1.5418 Å). Magnetic measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-7 SQUID magnetometer.

elements.content: A mixture of bib (0.044 g, 0.2 mmol), H2atibdc (0.120 g, 0.2 mmol), and Co­(Ac)2·4H2O (0.051 g, 0.2 mmol) in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 8 mL) and distilled water (2 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25 mL) and heated at 80 °C for 3 days and slowly cooled to room temperature (5 °C h–1). elements.content: Diffraction data for all complexes were collected at 296(2) K with a Bruker-AXS SMART CCD area detector diffractometer using ω rotation scans with a scan width of 0.3° and Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Absorption corrections were carried out utilizing SADABS routine. The structures were solved by the direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinements based on F 2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically with the hydrogen atoms added to their geometrically ideal positions and refined isotropically. Other details of crystal data, data collection parameters, and refinement statistics are given in . The selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1 in the Supporting Information.

Complex 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca and shows a two-dimensional (2D) network. The asymmetric unit contains one Co­(II) ion, one bib, and one atibdc2–. Each Co­(II) ion is four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 and O4) and two imidazole nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3). The Co–O and Co–N distances are 1.973(3), 2.001(3), 2.018(4), and 2.038(3) Å, respectively (a). Co­(II) ions are bridged by the carboxylic groups of atibdc2– anion to form a one-dimensional (1D) zigzag chain. The bib ligands adopt the trans-conformation to bridge the Co­(II) ions to give the left- and right-handed helical chains along the b-axis with a pitch of 17.495 Å (the distance was measured between two adjacent Co­(II) ions). These left- and right-handed helical chains [Co­(bib)] n are further connected by the 1D zigzag chains [Co­(atibdc)] n to generate a 2D wave-like network (b), which can be simplified as a 4-connected sql net (c).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of 1 

Complex 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca and shows a two-dimensional (2D) network. The asymmetric unit contains one Co(II) ion, one bib, and one atibdc2-. Each Co(II) ion is four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 and O4) and two imidazole nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3). The Co-O and Co-N distances are 1.973(3), 2.001(3), 2.018(4), and 2.038(3) Å, respectively (a). Co(II) ions are bridged by the carboxylic groups of atibdc2- anion to form a one-dimensional (1D) zigzag chain. The bib ligands adopt the trans-conformation to bridge the Co(II) ions to give the left- and right-handed helical chains along the b-axis with a pitch of 17.495 Å (the distance was measured between two adjacent Co(II) ions). These left- and right-handed helical chains [Co(bib)] n  are further connected by the 1D zigzag chains [Co(atibdc)] n  to generate a 2D wave-like network (b), which can be simplified as a 4-connected sql net (c).

elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The coordination environment of Co(II) ion in 1. (b) Left: zigzag chains, left-handed, and right-handed; right: 2D network (bright yellow and pink sticks represent atibdc2- and bib ligands, respectively); (c) 2D 4-connected sql network of 1.

elements.content: Because complexes 2M and 2P are enantiomers, we mainly focused on the structural details of 2M. X-ray crystallography revealed that 2M crystallizes in the orthorhombic chiral space group P212121 with a Flack parameter of −0.01(3), which indicates enantiomeric purity of the single crystals. The asymmetric unit of 2M contains one independent Co­(II) ion, one bib, and one atibdc2– anion. Similar to the structure of 1, in 2M, the Co­(II) ion exhibits a four-coordinated environment occupied by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and two imidazole nitrogen atoms [Co1–O2 = 1.960(4) Å, Co1–O4 = 1.944(4) Å, Co1–N1 = 1.996(5) Å, and Co1–N3 = 2.002(4) Å] (a). Along the a-axis, Co­(II) ions are bridged by the monodentate carboxylic groups to form a 1D left-handed [Co­(atibdc)] n helical chain with a pitch of 14.373 Å. Meanwhile, along the b-axis, the flexible bib ligands adopt the cis-conformation to bridge Co­(II) ions into a 1D right-handed [Co­(bib)] n helical chain with a helical pitch of 10.643 Å (b). Furthermore, the interconnection of Co­(II) ions by bib and atibdc2– linkers results into a 1D left-handed [Co2(bib)­(atibdc)] n helical chain along the c-axis, with a pitch of 18.271 Å. A three-dimensional (3D) network is generated by the combination of these left-handed [Co2(bib)­(atibdc)] n helical chains by sharing Co­(II) ions (c). The final structure can be regarded as a 4-connected dia network with a point symbol of 66 by denoting the Co­(II) ion as a four-connected node (d). It is noteworthy that there are no chiral materials involved in the whole synthesis. This self-assembly process leading to a pair of enantiomers from achiral precursors via spontaneous resolution is somewhat exceptional.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 2 

Because complexes 2M and 2P are enantiomers, we mainly focused on the structural details of 2M. X-ray crystallography revealed that 2M crystallizes in the orthorhombic chiral space group P212121 with a Flack parameter of -0.01(3), which indicates enantiomeric purity of the single crystals. The asymmetric unit of 2M contains one independent Co(II) ion, one bib, and one atibdc2- anion. Similar to the structure of 1, in 2M, the Co(II) ion exhibits a four-coordinated environment occupied by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and two imidazole nitrogen atoms [Co1-O2 = 1.960(4) Å, Co1-O4 = 1.944(4) Å, Co1-N1 = 1.996(5) Å, and Co1-N3 = 2.002(4) Å] (a). Along the a-axis, Co(II) ions are bridged by the monodentate carboxylic groups to form a 1D left-handed [Co(atibdc)] n  helical chain with a pitch of 14.373 Å. Meanwhile, along the b-axis, the flexible bib ligands adopt the cis-conformation to bridge Co(II) ions into a 1D right-handed [Co(bib)] n  helical chain with a helical pitch of 10.643 Å (b). Furthermore, the interconnection of Co(II) ions by bib and atibdc2- linkers results into a 1D left-handed [Co2(bib)(atibdc)] n  helical chain along the c-axis, with a pitch of 18.271 Å. A three-dimensional (3D) network is generated by the combination of these left-handed [Co2(bib)(atibdc)] n  helical chains by sharing Co(II) ions (c). The final structure can be regarded as a 4-connected dia network with a point symbol of 66 by denoting the Co(II) ion as a four-connected node (d). It is noteworthy that there are no chiral materials involved in the whole synthesis. This self-assembly process leading to a pair of enantiomers from achiral precursors via spontaneous resolution is somewhat exceptional.

elements.content: In complex 3, the building block of H2aipa was generated in situ reaction from H2atibdc. The C–I bonds break and iodine exists in the mother solution in the form of I– ions (the detailed experience process in Supporting Information, Figures S1–S4).
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description of 3 

In complex 3, the building block of H2aipa was generated in situ reaction from H2atibdc. The C-I bonds break and iodine exists in the mother solution in the form of I- ions (the detailed experience process in Supporting Information, Figures S1-S4).

elements.content: X-ray crystallography reveals that complex 3 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pnna. Its asymmetric unit contains one independent Co­(II) ion, half bib, and half fully deprotonated aipa2– anion. The central Co­(II) ion is also a four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and two imidazole nitrogen atoms [Co1–O1 = 1.941(3) Å, and Co1–N2 = 2.028(3) Å] (a). The aipa2– also adopts monodentate bridging coordination mode bridged Co­(II) ions to shape two kinds of left- and right-handed helical chains [Co­(aipa)] n along the b-axis with a pitch of 17.367 Å (b), and the adjacent chains linked together by bib ligands. Meanwhile, each bib adopts the trans-conformation to bridge Co­(II) ions into 1D meso-helical chain [Co­(bib)] n (c). The left- and right-handed helical chains [Co­(aipa)] n are further connected by the meso-helical chains [Co­(bib)] n to generate a 3D structure (d). The potential voids are large enough to allow three independent identical networks, leading to a 3D 3-fold interpenetrating architecture, and exhibit an 4-connected cds net with the point symbol of {65·8} (e).

Its asymmetric unit contains one independent Co(II) ion, half bib, and half fully deprotonated aipa2- anion. The central Co(II) ion is also a four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and two imidazole nitrogen atoms [Co1-O1 = 1.941(3) Å, and Co1-N2 = 2.028(3) Å] (a). The aipa2- also adopts monodentate bridging coordination mode bridged Co(II) ions to shape two kinds of left- and right-handed helical chains [Co(aipa)] n  along the b-axis with a pitch of 17.367 Å (b), and the adjacent chains linked together by bib ligands. Meanwhile, each bib adopts the trans-conformation to bridge Co(II) ions into 1D meso-helical chain [Co(bib)] n  (c). The left- and right-handed helical chains [Co(aipa)] n  are further connected by the meso-helical chains [Co(bib)] n  to generate a 3D structure (d). The potential voids are large enough to allow three independent identical networks, leading to a 3D 3-fold interpenetrating architecture, and exhibit an 4-connected cds net with the point symbol of {65⋅8} (e).

elements.content: The most outstanding structural feature is that the elimination of iodine occurred under a higher temperature condition, and a new linker 5-H2aipa was yielded. The elimination of iodine reaction during the construction of a coordination polymer has been observed first. To our best knowledge, this is also the first example of iodine elimination based on H2atibdc. Because of the steric effect of the three I atoms of H2atibdc, the interpenetrating did not occur in all the reported structures based on H2atibdc. As the departure of the iodine atoms, the steric effect of coordination is reduced, and thus, the structure of 3 could be interpenetrated.

elements.content: To better elucidate the result of 3, the same procedure was followed except that the initial H2atibdc ligand was replaced by 5-H2aipa; fortunately, complex 4 formulary as [Co2(bib)­(aipa)2]­·2H2O was obtained. Totally different from that of 3, the structure of 4 is a 2D double-layer based on 5-H2aipa and bib mixed ligands (Figure S5, Supporting Information); the crystal data and structure refinements for 4 are given in Table S2 in the Supporting Information. Furthermore, a series of experiments were also carried out, which demonstrate that complex 3 cannot be directly synthesized from the 5-H2aipa and bib with Co­(II) ions.

Furthermore, a series of experiments were also carried out, which demonstrate that complex 3 cannot be directly synthesized from the 5-H2aipa and bib with Co(II) ions.

elements.content: Using a reaction of the same initial reactants, complexes 1–3 were synthesized at three temperatures of 80, 130, and 150 °C, which show a 2D wave layer, 3D chiral structure, and 3D 3-fold interpenetrating framework, respectively. Evidently, with the temperature changed, complexes of 1–3 exhibit diverse structures. The coordination modes of carboxylic acid ligand are shown in . Particularly, at 150 °C, the C–I bonds of the H2atibdc ligand were cleaved, while this did not happen at 130 and 80 °C; this result should be attributed to the effects of temperature. In addition, when the temperature is below 80 °C or in the range of 160–200 °C, no coordination polymer could be obtained. It is clear that the temperature plays an important role in the formation of the diverse structures and topologies. The formation and/or crystallization of CPs are significantly influenced by the reaction temperature, solvent, metal cations, and so on. But a particular series of CPs species that can be systematically tuned by one factor and undergo structural transformations still remain largely unexplored thus far, and this work presents a good case of temperature effects.
elements.clean_text:
Effects of Temperature on the Structure

Using a reaction of the same initial reactants, complexes 1-3 were synthesized at three temperatures of 80, 130, and 150 °C, which show a 2D wave layer, 3D chiral structure, and 3D 3-fold interpenetrating framework, respectively. Evidently, with the temperature changed, complexes of 1-3 exhibit diverse structures. The coordination modes of carboxylic acid ligand are shown in . Particularly, at 150 °C, the C-I bonds of the H2atibdc ligand were cleaved, while this did not happen at 130 and 80 °C; this result should be attributed to the effects of temperature. In addition, when the temperature is below 80 °C or in the range of 160-200 °C, no coordination polymer could be obtained. It is clear that the temperature plays an important role in the formation of the diverse structures and topologies. The formation and/or crystallization of CPs are significantly influenced by the reaction temperature, solvent, metal cations, and so on. But a particular series of CPs species that can be systematically tuned by one factor and undergo structural transformations still remain largely unexplored thus far, and this work presents a good case of temperature effects.

elements.content: The experimental PXRD patterns of 1–3 demonstrate good agreement with the simulated ones (Figure S6, Supporting Information), indicating the phase purity. TGA was performed under N2 atmosphere on polycrystalline samples of 1–3 (Figure S7, Supporting Information). For 1, no weight loss was found before decomposition of the frameworks occurred at around 290 °C. For 2, it shows a weight loss of 4.19% before 94 °C, which due to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd. 4.14%). There is no weight loss or obvious heat change observed in the temperature range of 94–295 °C, and then the samples start to decompose at approximately 295 °C. For 3, the phase remains stable up to 376 °C until the organic ligands start to be released, exhibiting higher thermal stability than 1 and 2, and the reason should be due to the interpenetrating structure of 3.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and TGA

The experimental PXRD patterns of 1-3 demonstrate good agreement with the simulated ones (Figure S6, Supporting Information), indicating the phase purity. TGA was performed under N2 atmosphere on polycrystalline samples of 1-3 (Figure S7, Supporting Information). For 1, no weight loss was found before decomposition of the frameworks occurred at around 290 °C. For 2, it shows a weight loss of 4.19% before 94 °C, which due to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd. 4.14%). There is no weight loss or obvious heat change observed in the temperature range of 94-295 °C, and then the samples start to decompose at approximately 295 °C. For 3, the phase remains stable up to 376 °C until the organic ligands start to be released, exhibiting higher thermal stability than 1 and 2, and the reason should be due to the interpenetrating structure of 3.

elements.content: The solid crystals of 1, 2, and 3 were soaked in initial synthetic solvent and heated under three different temperatures (including 80, 130, and 150 °C). Interestingly, the structure of 2 changed to 1 when 2 was soaked in the initial synthetic solvent heated at 150 °C for 72 h, while it kept the same crystal morphology. The structural gradual transformation from 2 to 1 for bulk crystalline materials was further confirmed by PXRD patterns (). That is to say, the 3D coordination framework of [Co­(bib)­(atibdc)]­·2H2O (2) can suffer a SCSC structural transformation process to form a 2D supramolecular isomer of [Co­(bib)­(atibdc)] (1). A careful structural comparison of 1 and 2 indicates the considerable similarity of the Co­(II) coordination spheres and the binding modes of atibdc2–. The significant discrepancy of the structures of 1 and 2 should be exclusively attributed to the different configuration of bib as shown in and lattice water molecules; thus, the different stability of the configuration of bib and the hydrogen bond existing between the host and guest may lead to the structure transformation. To further understand this structural transformation, by heating the crystal samples of 2 at 110 °C in a vacuum for 10 h, the lattice water molecules could be completely removed, which was verified by TGA (Figure S8, Supporting Information), but the PXRD pattern indicates that 2 did not transform to 1 (Figure S9, Supporting Information), even when the heating time was extended. Thus, the SCSC transformation from 2 to 1 should be induced by temperature-solvent. In the solvothermal system, the flexible bib was preferred to transform to its trans-conformation, which caused structural rearrangement, the structure of 2 transformed to a more stable configuration, and 1 was generated. In addition, SCSC transformation from 1 to 2 via the above solvent or solid state heating treatment was not achieved, although numerous trials have been attempted; this also may be the more stable trans-conformation of bib in 1 than its cis-conformation in 2.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Transformation

The solid crystals of 1, 2, and 3 were soaked in initial synthetic solvent and heated under three different temperatures (including 80, 130, and 150 °C). Interestingly, the structure of 2 changed to 1 when 2 was soaked in the initial synthetic solvent heated at 150 °C for 72 h, while it kept the same crystal morphology. The structural gradual transformation from 2 to 1 for bulk crystalline materials was further confirmed by PXRD patterns (). That is to say, the 3D coordination framework of [Co(bib)(atibdc)]⋅2H2O (2) can suffer a SCSC structural transformation process to form a 2D supramolecular isomer of [Co(bib)(atibdc)] (1). A careful structural comparison of 1 and 2 indicates the considerable similarity of the Co(II) coordination spheres and the binding modes of atibdc2-. The significant discrepancy of the structures of 1 and 2 should be exclusively attributed to the different configuration of bib as shown in  and lattice water molecules; thus, the different stability of the configuration of bib and the hydrogen bond existing between the host and guest may lead to the structure transformation. To further understand this structural transformation, by heating the crystal samples of 2 at 110 °C in a vacuum for 10 h, the lattice water molecules could be completely removed, which was verified by TGA (Figure S8, Supporting Information), but the PXRD pattern indicates that 2 did not transform to 1 (Figure S9, Supporting Information), even when the heating time was extended. Thus, the SCSC transformation from 2 to 1 should be induced by temperature-solvent. In the solvothermal system, the flexible bib was preferred to transform to its trans-conformation, which caused structural rearrangement, the structure of 2 transformed to a more stable configuration, and 1 was generated. In addition, SCSC transformation from 1 to 2 via the above solvent or solid state heating treatment was not achieved, although numerous trials have been attempted; this also may be the more stable trans-conformation of bib in 1 than its cis-conformation in 2.

elements.content: The bulk crystals for 2M and 2P were crushed to powder and their solid-state CD property was measured by employing KBr plates. The CD spectrum for the bulk sample of 2M exhibits an obvious positive CD signal at 240 and 326 nm (), revealing its homochiral nature. A mirror image is observed for 2P, confirming that compounds 2M and 2P are enantiomers.
elements.clean_text:
Circular Dichroism (CD) Spectra

The bulk crystals for 2M and 2P were crushed to powder and their solid-state CD property was measured by employing KBr plates. The CD spectrum for the bulk sample of 2M exhibits an obvious positive CD signal at 240 and 326 nm (), revealing its homochiral nature. A mirror image is observed for 2P, confirming that compounds 2M and 2P are enantiomers.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibilities for complexes 1–3 was measured for the polycrystalline samples in the range of 1.9–300 K under 1000 Oe of an external field. As shown in a–c, the χM T value at 300 K of 1 is 2.50 cm3 K mol–1, 2 is 2.95 cm3 K mol–1, and 3 is 3.25 cm3 K mol–1, which are larger than the spin-only value of 1.88 cm3 K mol–1 (S = 3/2, g = 2) state based on one Co­(II) ion. The larger values are the result of contributions to the susceptibility from the orbital angular momentum at high temperature. Then they abruptly decreased to 1.50 cm3 K mol–1 for 1, 1.75 cm3 K mol–1 for 2, and 1.81 cm3 K mol–1 for 3 at 1.90 K, and this can be assigned to a large zero-field splitting (ZFS). In accordance with the Curie–Weiss law, χM = C/(T – θ), the data in the range of 1.9–300 K show a good linear relationship between χM –1 and T, with a Curie constant of C = 2.14 cm3 K mol–1 and a Weiss constant of θ = −10.41 K for 1, C = 2.13 cm3 K mol–1, θ = −10.34 K for 2, C = 2.34 cm3 K mol–1, θ = −10.34 K for 3. The moderate negative θ values of the Weiss constants indicate antiferromagnetic behavior of 1–3. In addition, the large separation between the neighboring Co­(II) cores is most probably the main reason for the weaker magnetic interaction.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibilities for complexes 1-3 was measured for the polycrystalline samples in the range of 1.9-300 K under 1000 Oe of an external field. As shown in a-c, the χM T value at 300 K of 1 is 2.50 cm3 K mol-1, 2 is 2.95 cm3 K mol-1, and 3 is 3.25 cm3 K mol-1, which are larger than the spin-only value of 1.88 cm3 K mol-1 (S = 3/2, g = 2) state based on one Co(II) ion. The larger values are the result of contributions to the susceptibility from the orbital angular momentum at high temperature. Then they abruptly decreased to 1.50 cm3 K mol-1 for 1, 1.75 cm3 K mol-1 for 2, and 1.81 cm3 K mol-1 for 3 at 1.90 K, and this can be assigned to a large zero-field splitting (ZFS). In accordance with the Curie-Weiss law, χM = C/(T - θ), the data in the range of 1.9-300 K show a good linear relationship between χM -1 and T, with a Curie constant of C = 2.14 cm3 K mol-1 and a Weiss constant of θ = -10.41 K for 1, C = 2.13 cm3 K mol-1, θ = -10.34 K for 2, C = 2.34 cm3 K mol-1, θ = -10.34 K for 3. The moderate negative θ values of the Weiss constants indicate antiferromagnetic behavior of 1-3. In addition, the large separation between the neighboring Co(II) cores is most probably the main reason for the weaker magnetic interaction.

elements.content: In conclusion, on the basis of the same reactants, by controlling the reaction temperature, three new CPs have been successfully constructed. The preparing conditions of 1, 2 (2M and 2P), and 3 fully indicate that the temperature plays an important role in the preparation of CPs. With the increase of temperature, structures of 1–3 get gradually complicated. Importantly, an uncommon in situ iodine elimination reaction during the construction of CPs has been obtained. Moreover, a unique single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation has occurred by cooperation of temperature and solvent. We think the results could provide new insights into the construction and modulation of advanced crystalline materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, on the basis of the same reactants, by controlling the reaction temperature, three new CPs have been successfully constructed. The preparing conditions of 1, 2 (2M and 2P), and 3 fully indicate that the temperature plays an important role in the preparation of CPs. With the increase of temperature, structures of 1-3 get gradually complicated. Importantly, an uncommon in situ iodine elimination reaction during the construction of CPs has been obtained. Moreover, a unique single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation has occurred by cooperation of temperature and solvent. We think the results could provide new insights into the construction and modulation of advanced crystalline materials.

A mixture of bib (0.044 g, 0.2 mmol), H2atibdc (0.120 g, 0.2 mmol), and Co­(Ac)2·4H2O (0.051 g, 0.2 mmol) in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 8 mL) and distilled water (2 mL) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25 mL) and heated at 80 °C for 3 days and slowly cooled to room temperature (5 °C h–1). Dark blue block crystals of 1 were isolated by washing with DMF and H2O, and dried in air. The yield was 80.56% based on Co. Anal. Elemental analysis: calc. for C20H20CoI3N5O4: C, 28.80; H, 2.42; N, 8.40; found: C, 28.89; H, 2.33; N, 8.31. The procedure was the same as with 1, except that the temperature was raised to 130 °C. Dark blue block crystals of 2M and 2P were isolated by washing with DMF and H2O, and dried in air. The yield was 70.21% based on Co. Anal. Elemental analysis: calc. for C20H24CoI3N5O6: C, 27.61; H, 2.78; N, 8.05; found: C, 27.55; H, 2.91; N, 8.14. cln_elements.content:
Complex 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca and shows a two-dimensional (2D) network. The asymmetric unit contains one Co­(II) ion, one bib, and one atibdc2–. Each Co­(II) ion is four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 and O4) and two imidazole nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3). The Co–O and Co–N distances are 1.973(3), 2.001(3), 2.018(4), and 2.038(3) Å, respectively (a). Co­(II) ions are bridged by the carboxylic groups of atibdc2– anion to form a one-dimensional (1D) zigzag chain. The bib ligands adopt the trans-conformation to bridge the Co­(II) ions to give the left- and right-handed helical chains along the b-axis with a pitch of 17.495 Å (the distance was measured between two adjacent Co­(II) ions). These left- and right-handed helical chains [Co­(bib)] n are further connected by the 1D zigzag chains [Co­(atibdc)] n to generate a 2D wave-like network (b), which can be simplified as a 4-connected sql net (c).

PXRD and TGA

The experimental PXRD patterns of 1–3 demonstrate good agreement with the simulated ones (Figure S6, Supporting Information), indicating the phase purity. TGA was performed under N2 atmosphere on polycrystalline samples of 1–3 (Figure S7, Supporting Information). For 1, no weight loss was found before decomposition of the frameworks occurred at around 290 °C. For 2, it shows a weight loss of 4.19% before 94 °C, which due to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd. 4.14%). There is no weight loss or obvious heat change observed in the temperature range of 94–295 °C, and then the samples start to decompose at approximately 295 °C. For 3, the phase remains stable up to 376 °C until the organic ligands start to be released, exhibiting higher thermal stability than 1 and 2, and the reason should be due to the interpenetrating structure of 3.

Magnetic Properties

Temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibilities for complexes 1–3 was measured for the polycrystalline samples in the range of 1.9–300 K under 1000 Oe of an external field. As shown in a–c, the χM T value at 300 K of 1 is 2.50 cm3 K mol–1, 2 is 2.95 cm3 K mol–1, and 3 is 3.25 cm3 K mol–1, which are larger than the spin-only value of 1.88 cm3 K mol–1 (S = 3/2, g = 2) state based on one Co­(II) ion. The larger values are the result of contributions to the susceptibility from the orbital angular momentum at high temperature. Then they abruptly decreased to 1.50 cm3 K mol–1 for 1, 1.75 cm3 K mol–1 for 2, and 1.81 cm3 K mol–1 for 3 at 1.90 K, and this can be assigned to a large zero-field splitting (ZFS). In accordance with the Curie–Weiss law, χM = C/(T – θ), the data in the range of 1.9–300 K show a good linear relationship between χM –1 and T, with a Curie constant of C = 2.14 cm3 K mol–1 and a Weiss constant of θ = −10.41 K for 1, C = 2.13 cm3 K mol–1, θ = −10.34 K for 2, C = 2.34 cm3 K mol–1, θ = −10.34 K for 3. The moderate negative θ values of the Weiss constants indicate antiferromagnetic behavior of 1–3. In addition, the large separation between the neighboring Co­(II) cores is most probably the main reason for the weaker magnetic interaction.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of 1 

Complex 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca and shows a two-dimensional (2D) network. The asymmetric unit contains one Co(II) ion, one bib, and one atibdc2-. Each Co(II) ion is four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 and O4) and two imidazole nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3). The Co-O and Co-N distances are 1.973(3), 2.001(3), 2.018(4), and 2.038(3) Å, respectively (a). Co(II) ions are bridged by the carboxylic groups of atibdc2- anion to form a one-dimensional (1D) zigzag chain. The bib ligands adopt the trans-conformation to bridge the Co(II) ions to give the left- and right-handed helical chains along the b-axis with a pitch of 17.495 Å (the distance was measured between two adjacent Co(II) ions). These left- and right-handed helical chains [Co(bib)] n  are further connected by the 1D zigzag chains [Co(atibdc)] n  to generate a 2D wave-like network (b), which can be simplified as a 4-connected sql net (c).

PXRD and TGA

The experimental PXRD patterns of 1-3 demonstrate good agreement with the simulated ones (Figure S6, Supporting Information), indicating the phase purity. TGA was performed under N2 atmosphere on polycrystalline samples of 1-3 (Figure S7, Supporting Information). For 1, no weight loss was found before decomposition of the frameworks occurred at around 290 °C. For 2, it shows a weight loss of 4.19% before 94 °C, which due to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd. 4.14%). There is no weight loss or obvious heat change observed in the temperature range of 94-295 °C, and then the samples start to decompose at approximately 295 °C. For 3, the phase remains stable up to 376 °C until the organic ligands start to be released, exhibiting higher thermal stability than 1 and 2, and the reason should be due to the interpenetrating structure of 3.

Magnetic Properties

Temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibilities for complexes 1-3 was measured for the polycrystalline samples in the range of 1.9-300 K under 1000 Oe of an external field. As shown in a-c, the χM T value at 300 K of 1 is 2.50 cm3 K mol-1, 2 is 2.95 cm3 K mol-1, and 3 is 3.25 cm3 K mol-1, which are larger than the spin-only value of 1.88 cm3 K mol-1 (S = 3/2, g = 2) state based on one Co(II) ion. The larger values are the result of contributions to the susceptibility from the orbital angular momentum at high temperature. Then they abruptly decreased to 1.50 cm3 K mol-1 for 1, 1.75 cm3 K mol-1 for 2, and 1.81 cm3 K mol-1 for 3 at 1.90 K, and this can be assigned to a large zero-field splitting (ZFS). In accordance with the Curie-Weiss law, χM = C/(T - θ), the data in the range of 1.9-300 K show a good linear relationship between χM -1 and T, with a Curie constant of C = 2.14 cm3 K mol-1 and a Weiss constant of θ = -10.41 K for 1, C = 2.13 cm3 K mol-1, θ = -10.34 K for 2, C = 2.34 cm3 K mol-1, θ = -10.34 K for 3. The moderate negative θ values of the Weiss constants indicate antiferromagnetic behavior of 1-3. In addition, the large separation between the neighboring Co(II) cores is most probably the main reason for the weaker magnetic interaction.
